intro: Cirsium syriacum var. bracteatum, commonly known as the Syrian thistle, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the Middle East and parts of Central Asia. It typically grows to a height of 60–120 cm, featuring erect, spiny stems covered in fine hairs. The plant produces large, showy purple to pink flower heads, which are surrounded by bracts that give it its specific name. Its leaves are deeply lobed and covered in stiff, prickly hairs, contributing to its defensive characteristics. This species is often found in rocky or arid habitats, where it thrives in well-drained soils.
